metadata.case_name: N. S. Mooss v. State of Kerala & Ors.

facts.text: Kattayam Electric Supply Agency, Kottayam, is the licensee for supply of electric energy in Kottayam, Kerala. Appellant N. S. Mooss is the proprietor.
On June 21, 1962, State Government sent letter No. 11795-EL 1/61/17/P.W. to Kerala Electricity Board seeking views on revocation of licence under s.4(1)(a).
On July 26, 1962, Board replied vide No. B.VII/57051/62 recommending revocation.
On August 17, 1962, State Government issued notice under s.4(3) to appellant asking to show cause why licence should not be revoked, within three months and three days.
On November 5, 1962, appellant sent explanation to Government.
On May 17, 1963, State Government passed order revoking licence with effect from August 1, 1963 under s.5(1)(a).
On May 17, 1963, State Government passed another order under s.5(1)(c) and (3) directing appellant to deliver undertaking to Board on or before July 1, 1963.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art.226 in Kerala High Court (O.P. No.1138/1963) challenging the two orders.
Kerala High Court dismissed the writ petition on February 1, 1965.
On April 6, 1963, Government sent letter No.11795-WY/61-20/PW to Board stating explanation considered unsatisfactory, decided to revoke, enquiring under s.5(b) if Board willing to purchase.
On April 20, 1963, Board replied vide LAW 5705-62/20-4-63 willing to purchase from August 1, 1963.

legal_issues.text: Whether the State Electricity Board was duly consulted after receipt of licensee's explanation before revocation of licence under s.4 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910, as required by the amended provision 'after consulting the State Electricity Board'.
Whether the point regarding lack of due consultation was raised in the writ petition and High Court, allowing it to be urged in Supreme Court.
Whether the provision for consulting the Board in s.4 is mandatory or directory.

petitioner_arguments.text: Board endorsed revocation proposal before appellant's explanation reached State; explanation not placed before or considered by Board; no due consultation; revocation order void.

respondent_arguments.text: Point not raised in writ petition or High Court; should not be allowed in Supreme Court.
Appellant's objections considered; consulted Board; orders passed in accordance with Act.
Provision for consultation directory, not mandatory; non-compliance does not nullify order.
Board consulted only on public interest or at provisional stage sufficient.

court_reasoning.text: Point embedded in paras 6 and 22 of writ affidavit; respondents understood and controverted it; facts on record; goes to root; allow to be raised despite not urged in High Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No prejudice to respondents; no second consultation possible as per correspondence.

court_reasoning.text: s.4 as amended requires consultation after show cause notice and explanation; Board must consider explanation to recommend revocation, non-revocation, or continuance with conditions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Premature consultation before explanation; Board could not consider it.

court_reasoning.text: Consultation mandatory condition precedent like other clauses in s.4; breach makes order void; introduced as safeguard post-Art.19(1)(g); Board independent expert body.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Drastic power; prevents bias from provisional views.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes precedents like Manbodhan Lal Srivastava (Art.320(3) directory due to proviso, different chapter); here no waiver provision, inserted for licensee safeguard.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Board's opinion not binding but imperative condition.

holdings.text: Consultation of Board under s.4 must be after licensee's explanation; premature consultation renders revocation order void.
Provision 'after consulting the State Electricity Board' in s.4 is mandatory.

precedents_cited.relevance: Art.320(3) directory; dissimilar as no waiver proviso here, different context.

precedents_cited.relevance: No new issue of fact permitted.

precedents_cited.relevance: No new issue of fact permitted.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Electricity Act, 1910
statutes_cited.relevance: Revocation of licence requires notice, consideration of explanation, consultation with Board after explanation; mandatory, breach voids order.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Electricity (Supply) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Board is corporate body; decisions authenticated by Chairman; no telephonic consultation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Right to business; reasonable hearing; writ jurisdiction; distinguished Art.320.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; writ petition allowed; notice dated 17-8-1962, revocation order dated 17-5-1963, and delivery order dated 17-5-1963 quashed as void for lack of due consultation with Board after explanation.
outcome.costs: Appellant shall not get costs in this Court or High Court.

key_quotes.text: "We are accordingly of opinion that s.4 contemplates that the Board should make its recommendation only after considering the explanation of the licensee."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on timing of consultation.

key_quotes.text: "Having regard to the object and context, we are of the view that the condition of consulting the Board is mandatory and the breach of this condition will make the order of revocation void."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "First impressions and provisional judgments have a tendency to become ultimate ideas and final judgments."
key_quotes.speaker: court
